# Overview

<a href="https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/books.html"><img src="https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/images/cover.png" alt="R Markdown: The Definitive Guide" width="250" style="padding: 0 15px; float: right;"/></a>

If you are new to **bookdown**, we encourage you to start at <https://bookdown.org> which offers a Getting starting section and an overview of book examples made with **bookdown**. 

The specific chapter on _Books_ in [R Markdown: The Definitive Guide](https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/books.html) is also a great place to start before going through the [User Guide](#user-guide). This books will also give you a lot of information about R Markdown and its features.


# User Guide

<a href="https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/"><img src="https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/images/cover.jpg" alt="bookdown: Authoring Books and Technical Documents with R Markdown" width="250" style="padding: 0 15px; float: right;"/></a>

Written by Yihui Xie, the package author, [bookdown: Authoring Books and Technical Documents with R Markdown](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/) provides a short book introducing the R package, bookdown, to change your workflow of writing books. The book is published by Chapman & Hall/CRC, and you can read it online for free.

The book is structured into several chapters to guide the reader into the use of the R package **bookdown** to write books: 

```{r, results='asis', echo = FALSE, eval = FALSE}
# run this to update the content below
xfun::pkg_attach2("xml2")
html <- read_html("https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/")
chapters <- xml_find_all(html, "//li[@class='chapter']")
first_level <- chapters[which(purrr::map_lgl(xml_attr(chapters, 'data-level'), ~ grepl('^\\d+$', .x)))]
titles <- xml_text(xml_find_all(first_level, "a"))
titles <- gsub("^(\\d+)", "\\1.", titles)
titles <- gsub("^(.*) \\([*])$", "\\1", titles)
url <- file.path("https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown", xml_attr(first_level, "data-path"))
formatted <- sprintf("* [%s](%s)", titles, url)
cat(formatted, sep = "\n")
```

* [1. Introduction](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/introduction.html) introduces the package and gives the main information to get starting.
* [2. Components](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/components.html) gives detailed information of the elements than can be used in a book from Markdown syntax, to custom blocks, presenting also special features brought by **bookdown** to the R markdown format as Theorem and Proof environments or numbered references.
* [3. Output Formats](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/output-formats.html) is the document of the special formats to produce HTML, PDF or EPUB books. 
* [4. Customization](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/customization.html) is the documentation of all the configuration option available for customization.
* [5. Editing](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/editing.html) explains how to edit, build, preview, and serve the book locally.
* [6. Publishing](https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/publishing.html) gives information on how to publish early online for feedbacks, or formally publish as either printed copies or e-books.

# Going further wih examples

<https://bookdown.org> is the main place to find examples of books created with **bookdown**

* The [Home](https://bookdown.org/home/) section showcases some featured book available online from which you should be able to look at the source
* The [Books](https://bookdown.org/home/archive/) section will list all the book published in _bookdown.org_ hosting service.
* The [Contest](https://bookdown.org/home/contest/) section showcases the award recipients and their bookdown applications from the [first bookdown contest](https://blog.rstudio.com/2018/07/27/first-bookdown-contest/) launched in 2018.
